newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan's Zara to raise capital by 15 mln dinars.
newsitem.headline: Jordan's Zara to raise capital by 15 mln dinars.

text.p: Zara Investments, Jordan's leading holding company for tourism investments, announced on Tuesday a private placement to raise its capital to 40 million dinars ($56 million) from 25 million within a month, company officials said.
The private placement will be offered to its 147 existing shareholders, with a closing date of November 16.

"The capital increase will finance some of the capital costs of our estimated $180 million worth of projects that are due for completion by 1999," Saleh al-Rifai, general manager of Zara Investments Holdings Company, told Reuters.

Zara, listed on the primary market of the Amman exchange, was set up in 1994 by investors and institutions, with a key 16 percent stake held by Cairo-Amman Bank and similar stakes by two leading Jordanian investors, Khalil Talhouni and Sabih al-Masri.
The company, which is pinning its hopes on a tourism boom after Jordan's peace treaty with Israel, acquired a 27.7 percent stake in the five-star Amman InterContinental.
A $20 million expansion programme is under way to add an extra 150 rooms, a mall and a health club by 1998.
Rifai said Zara had already received a commitment from the IFC, the World Bank's private investment arm, to take a $3 million stake in its equity capital.
Arab Bank was also negotiating to enter as a shareholder but no final agreement has been reached yet, Rifai added.
Rifai said the IFC had agreed to provide a $15 million loan to the company's three main projects currently under construction.

The projects include a 313-room five star hotel in Amman to be managed by U.S chain Hyatt Regency. The hotel is expected to be ready by end 1998 at a cost of around $42 million. An adjoining $30 million trade centre is under construction.
A $35 million 231-room Dead Sea village resort, to be managed by Switzerland's Moevenpick, will be opened in the first quarter of 1999.
Zara recently opened a 179-room hotel, also managed by Moevenpick, in the Nabatean city of Petra at a cost of around 14 million dinars ($20 million).
